subject: Photography
title: Aperture: The Eye of the Lens
description: A quick, practical guide to Aperture: The Eye of the Lens.

hook.text: Inside every lens is a hole that opens and closes â€” like the pupil of your eye. It controls everything.

buildup.text: Aperture is the adjustable opening inside a lens. A wider aperture lets in more light; a narrower one lets in less.

discovery.text: Aperture is measured in f-stops. The confusing part: a smaller f-number means a bigger opening.

twist.text: Aperture also controls depth of field. Wide open, backgrounds blur. Stopped down, everything stays sharp.

climax.text: Portrait photographers love wide apertures for creamy blur. Landscape photographers stop down for total sharpness.

punchline.text: Small number, big hole. Photography loves contradictions.

quiz.question: What does a smaller f-number (like f/1.8) mean?
options: A larger lens opening letting in more light
